sections.content: Organizing and presenting data is always an important feature within any application, and Desk is no exception. Using the Analytics module, we can create reports and components to help represent the data in a way useful for a team. This can be anything from getting a report that shows a trend in the amount of requests related to a specific subject, to tracking the amount of replies an agent has sent out for the day. Essentially, Analytics gives a team the tools and data to help them make accurate business decisions.

items: Showcase and demonstrate the creation and use of Reports and Components within the Analytics module
Understand the differences between static and custom reports
Learn when to use different report types (Summary, Tabular, Matrix)
Create dashboards to visualize support metrics

sections.content: Reports are the foundation of analytics in Zoho Desk. They allow you to extract, organize, and analyze data from your support operations to gain insights and make informed decisions.
Navigate to the **Analytics** tab in the main navigation to access the reporting interface. Here you'll find pre-built reports and the ability to create custom reports.
Static reports are pre-configured reports provided by Zoho Desk that cover common support metrics and use cases. These reports are ready to use out of the box and require no configuration.

items: **Tickets by Status:** Shows ticket distribution across different statuses
**Tickets by Priority:** Breakdown of tickets by priority levels
**Agent Performance:** Metrics on agent activity, response times, and resolution rates
**SLA Compliance:** Tracks adherence to service level agreements
**Customer Satisfaction:** CSAT scores and trends over time
**Channel Performance:** Ticket volume by channel (email, chat, phone, etc.)
**Time-based Metrics:** Response time, resolution time, and first contact resolution

sections.content: **Use Case:** Static reports are perfect for quick insights and standard metrics. Start with static reports to understand available data before building custom reports.
Custom reports allow you to create tailored reports that match your specific business needs. You control which data is included, how it's grouped, what filters are applied, and how it's visualized.

items: Static reports don't provide the exact metrics you need
You need to analyze data from a unique perspective or combination of fields
You want to track custom fields or specific business processes
You need to filter data in ways not available in static reports
You want to create department-specific or role-specific reports

sections.content: Zoho Desk offers three types of custom reports, each suited for different analysis needs. Understanding when to use each type is crucial for effective reporting.
Summary reports group data and provide aggregate calculations (count, sum, average, etc.) for each group. They're ideal for high-level overviews and trend analysis.

items: Group data by one or more fields (e.g., by Department, by Status, by Agent)
Calculate aggregates like Count, Sum, Average, Min, Max
Show subtotals for each group
Display data in collapsed format for easy scanning
Best for answering "how many" or "how much" questions

sections.content: **Example:** Create a summary report showing ticket count by Status, grouped by Agent. This quickly shows each agent's workload distribution across Open, Pending, and Closed tickets.

items: You need to see totals or averages for groups of records
You want to compare metrics across different categories
You're creating charts or visualizations (summary reports work best with charts)
You don't need to see individual record details
You want a high-level dashboard view

sections.content: Tabular reports display data in a simple table format, showing individual records with selected columns. Think of them as customizable list views with more flexibility.

items: Show individual records as rows
Select specific columns to display
Apply filters to narrow down results
Sort by any column
Export to CSV or Excel for further analysis
Best for detailed, record-level analysis

sections.content: **Example:** Create a tabular report listing all High Priority tickets with columns for Ticket Number, Subject, Agent, Status, and Created Date. This provides a detailed view for investigation or follow-up.

items: You need to see individual record details
You want to export a list of records for external processing
You're investigating specific tickets or patterns
You need to review detailed information for auditing or compliance
You want to create a filtered list for manual review

sections.content: Matrix reports provide a grid view with data grouped by both rows and columns, creating a cross-tabulation. They're powerful for comparing multiple dimensions simultaneously.

items: Group data by rows (e.g., Agent) and columns (e.g., Status)
See intersections of two groupings at once
Calculate aggregates for each cell, row, and column
Identify patterns across multiple dimensions
Best for complex comparative analysis

sections.content: **Example:** Create a matrix report with Agents as rows and Status as columns, showing ticket count for each combination. This reveals at a glance which agents have how many Open, Pending, and Closed tickets.

items: You need to analyze data across two dimensions simultaneously
You want to compare metrics in a grid format
You're looking for patterns or anomalies in cross-categorized data
You need a compact view of complex relationships
You want to create heat map visualizations

sections.content:
**Choosing the Right Report Type:**

**Tabular:** Need record details? Use Tabular.

**Summary:** Need grouped totals for charts? Use Summary.

**Matrix:** Need to compare two dimensions? Use Matrix.
Follow these steps to create a custom report in Zoho Desk:

items: Navigate to **Analytics > Reports**
Click **Create Report** or **New Report**
Select the module to report on (Tickets, Contacts, Accounts, etc.)
Choose the report type (Summary, Tabular, or Matrix)
Select the columns/fields to include in your report
Configure grouping (for Summary and Matrix reports)
Set filters to narrow down the data (e.g., Department = Technical Support, Created Time = Last Month)
Configure sorting and ordering
Preview the report to verify data
Save the report with a descriptive name
Share with specific users, teams, or make it public

sections.content: Filters control which records appear in your report. Use filters to focus on specific subsets of data:

items: **Time-based filters:** Created Time, Modified Time, Closed Time (Today, Yesterday, This Week, This Month, Last Month, This Quarter, Custom Range)
**Status filters:** Status, Sub-status, Resolution Status
**Assignment filters:** Department, Agent, Team
**Priority filters:** Priority level
**Custom field filters:** Any custom fields you've created
**Multiple filters:** Combine filters with AND/OR logic for complex criteria

sections.content: **Tip:** Use relative date filters like "This Month" or "Last 30 Days" instead of fixed dates. This ensures your report stays current automatically without manual updates.
Global reports provide cross-department visibility by aggregating data from all departments in your organization.

items: Pull data from multiple departments simultaneously
Provide organization-wide metrics and trends
Useful for executives and managers overseeing multiple support teams
Can compare performance across departments
Require appropriate permissions to create and view

sections.content: **Use Case:** Create a global report showing total ticket volume by department to understand which teams are handling the most support requests and may need additional resources.
Scheduled reports automatically run at specified intervals and email the results to designated recipients. This ensures stakeholders receive regular updates without manual report generation.

items: **Frequency:** Daily, Weekly, Monthly, or Custom intervals
**Time:** Choose specific time of day for report execution
**Recipients:** Send to specific users, teams, or external email addresses
**Format:** Choose between PDF, Excel, or CSV formats
**Conditions:** Only send if certain conditions are met (e.g., if SLA breaches > 0)

sections.content: **Example:** Schedule a weekly summary report of all High Priority tickets to be sent to the support manager every Monday morning at 8 AM, ensuring they start the week with current information.

items: Create or open an existing report
Click the **Schedule** button or option
Choose frequency (Daily, Weekly, Monthly)
Select the day(s) and time for report execution
Add email recipients (users or external addresses)
Select the export format (PDF, Excel, CSV)
Configure optional conditions for sending
Save the schedule

sections.content: Charts transform report data into visual representations, making trends and patterns easier to identify and understand. Most report types (especially Summary reports) can be visualized as charts.

items: **Column Chart:** Compare values across categories (good for showing ticket counts by status)
**Bar Chart:** Horizontal version of column chart (good when category names are long)
**Line Chart:** Show trends over time (perfect for tracking ticket volume by week or month)
**Pie Chart:** Show proportions and percentages (useful for showing ticket distribution by department)
**Donut Chart:** Similar to pie chart with a hole in the center (modern alternative to pie)
**Area Chart:** Similar to line chart but with filled area below the line
**Funnel Chart:** Show progressive reduction through stages (good for showing ticket lifecycle)
**Table Chart:** Display data in table format with visual enhancements

sections.content:
**Best Practice:** Choose chart types based on your data:

- **Comparisons:** Column/Bar charts
- **Trends over time:** Line/Area charts
- **Proportions:** Pie/Donut charts
- **Progressive stages:** Funnel charts

items: Create or open a Summary or Matrix report (Tabular reports have limited chart options)
Click the **Chart** button or icon
Select the chart type that best represents your data
Configure chart settings: X-axis (categories), Y-axis (values), Legend, Colors
Customize chart appearance (title, labels, colors)
Save the chart
Add the chart to a dashboard (covered next)

sections.content: Dashboards are customizable pages that display multiple reports, charts, and components together, providing a comprehensive view of your support operations at a glance.
Dashboards consolidate multiple analytics components into a single, easy-to-read interface. They're designed for quick insights and monitoring of key metrics.

items: **Multiple Components:** Combine reports, charts, KPIs, and metrics on one page
**Real-time Data:** Components update automatically with current data
**Customizable Layout:** Drag and drop components, resize, and arrange as needed
**Role-specific Views:** Create different dashboards for managers, agents, executives
**Interactive:** Click on components to drill down into detailed reports

sections.content: **Use Case:** Create a "Support Manager Dashboard" with components showing: Total tickets by status, Average response time, SLA compliance rate, Agent performance metrics, Top 5 most common issues.
Components are individual elements that display data on a dashboard. Each component is based on a report or metric.

items: **Chart Component:** Display a chart generated from a report
**KPI Component:** Show a single key metric with a large number (e.g., "247 Open Tickets")
**Table Component:** Display report data in table format
**Metric Component:** Show calculated values or comparisons (e.g., "Response Time: 2.5 hours â†“15%")
**Target Meter:** Visual gauge showing progress toward a goal
Navigate to **Analytics > Dashboards**
Click **Create Dashboard** or **New Dashboard**
Give your dashboard a descriptive name
Click **Add Component** to start adding elements
Select the component type (Chart, KPI, Table, etc.)
Choose the report or metric the component will display
Configure the component appearance and settings
Position and resize the component on the dashboard canvas
Repeat to add multiple components
Arrange components in a logical layout (most important metrics at the top)
Save the dashboard
Share the dashboard with specific users, teams, or make it public

sections.content:
**Layout Tip:** Organize dashboards with a clear hierarchy:
- **Top row:** High-level KPIs (total tickets, satisfaction score, SLA compliance)
- **Middle rows:** Trend charts (ticket volume over time, response time trends)
- **Bottom rows:** Detailed breakdowns (tickets by agent, tickets by category)

items: **Focus on Key Metrics:** Don't overcrowd dashboards - include only the most important information
**Use Consistent Time Periods:** Ensure all components use the same time range for accurate comparison
**Choose Appropriate Visualizations:** Match chart types to data (trends = line charts, comparisons = bar charts)
**Update Regularly:** Review and refine dashboards based on changing business needs
**Create Role-specific Dashboards:** Executives need different metrics than agents or team leads
**Use Color Strategically:** Green for positive metrics, red for issues needing attention
**Include Context:** Add titles and descriptions so viewers understand what they're seeing
**Make It Interactive:** Enable drill-down functionality so users can explore details
**Start with Questions:** Define what you want to learn before building reports
**Use Consistent Metrics:** Standardize how you measure performance across teams
**Regular Review Cycles:** Schedule weekly or monthly report reviews with your team
**Validate Data:** Periodically check report accuracy against actual records
**Document Reports:** Add descriptions explaining what each report shows and how to interpret it
**Archive Unused Reports:** Keep your reports library organized by removing obsolete reports
**Train Your Team:** Ensure agents and managers know how to read and interpret reports
**Act on Insights:** Analytics are only valuable if you use them to drive improvements

sections.content: Complete the following analytics exercises to gain hands-on experience:
Activity 1: Create a Custom Summary Report

items: Navigate to **Analytics > Reports**
Click **Create Report** and select the Tickets module
Choose **Summary Report** as the report type
Configure the report to show: How many tickets you have created under each status (Open, Closed, Pending, etc.), Grouped by the agent assigned to them (Ticket Owner)
Include columns that you feel might be useful for this analysis (Examples: Ticket Number, Subject, Priority, Department, Created Time, Closed Time, Response Time)
Apply filters if desired (e.g., Created Time = Last 30 Days, Department = Your Test Department)
Add grouping: Primary grouping by Ticket Owner (Agent), Secondary grouping by Status
Configure aggregates to show ticket count for each group
Preview the report to verify data appears correctly
Experiment with different column selections to see what provides the most insight
Save the report with a descriptive name (e.g., "Tickets by Agent and Status")

sections.content: Activity 2: Create a Chart and Dashboard

items: Open the report you created in Activity 1
Click the **Chart** button to generate a visual representation
Try different chart types: Column chart showing ticket counts by agent, Stacked column chart showing status breakdown per agent, Bar chart if agent names are long
Select the chart type that best represents your data
Customize the chart appearance (colors, title, labels)
Save the chart
Navigate to **Analytics > Dashboards**
Click **Create Dashboard** and give it a name (e.g., "My Test Dashboard" or "Agent Performance Dashboard")
Add the chart you just created as a component on the dashboard
Add at least 2 more components: A KPI component showing total ticket count, A table component showing the detailed report data, Or another chart from a different report
Arrange the components in a logical layout
Resize components for optimal viewing
Save the dashboard
Share the dashboard with yourself or make it private for testing

sections.content:
**Reflection Questions:** After creating your report and dashboard, consider:
- What insights does this data provide about agent workload?
- Are tickets distributed evenly across agents?
- Which status has the most tickets?
- How could you use this information to improve support operations?

**Step Beyond:** Check out the options available under **Data Administration**. Attempt to import some records into Desk using test data. You can use ChatGPT to generate fake test records in CSV format, then import them to see how bulk data operations work.

items: Open one of your existing reports
Click the **Schedule** option
Set up a schedule: Frequency: Weekly (every Monday), Time: 8:00 AM, Recipients: Your email address
Choose export format (Excel or PDF)
Save the schedule
Wait for the scheduled time or test the schedule by changing it to execute soon
Verify you receive the report via email at the scheduled time
**Static Reports:** Pre-configured reports for common metrics, ready to use out of the box
**Custom Reports:** Tailored reports matching specific business needs and analysis requirements
**Summary Reports:** Group data with aggregates, best for high-level overviews and charts
**Tabular Reports:** Show individual records in table format, best for detailed analysis
**Matrix Reports:** Cross-tabulation grid view, best for comparing two dimensions simultaneously
**Report Filters:** Time-based, status, assignment, priority, custom fields - use AND/OR logic
**Global Reports:** Cross-department visibility with organization-wide metrics
**Scheduled Reports:** Automated report execution and email delivery at specified intervals
**Chart Types:** Column, Bar, Line, Pie, Donut, Area, Funnel, Table - choose based on data
**Dashboards:** Consolidate multiple reports, charts, and KPIs into single customizable page
**Components:** Chart, KPI, Table, Metric, Target Meter - individual dashboard elements
**Best Practices:** Start with questions, use consistent metrics, regular reviews, act on insights

sections.content: After completing this lesson, you should be able to:

items: Explain the purpose and value of analytics in support operations
Distinguish between static and custom reports
Identify when to use Summary, Tabular, and Matrix report types
Create a Summary report with grouping and aggregates
Create a Tabular report showing individual record details
Create a Matrix report for cross-dimensional analysis
Apply filters to reports to focus on specific data subsets
Use relative date filters for automatically updating reports
Understand the purpose and use of global reports
Schedule reports for automated execution and email delivery
Generate charts from report data
Choose appropriate chart types for different data visualizations
Create dashboards to consolidate multiple analytics components
Add and configure components on dashboards (Chart, KPI, Table)
Arrange dashboard layouts for optimal information hierarchy
Share reports and dashboards with appropriate users or teams
Apply analytics best practices for effective data-driven decision making
Export reports in various formats (CSV, Excel, PDF)
Interpret report data to identify trends, patterns, and areas for improvement
Use analytics to monitor SLA compliance, agent performance, and customer satisfaction
